When in Rome…
I visited the place of the Council of Trent
description:
I recently was in Trento, Italy, visiting the location where the Council of Trent took place. Trent, which took place between 1545-63, was the most important movement of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, the Catholic Church’s first significant reply to the growing Protestants Reformation.

The location of Trent was strategic: taking place in northern Italy, a city on the border between Italy and Germany, making it a bridge between the Papal states and the territories of the Holy Roman Emperor. 

Initially Protestant leaders were invited as an act of unification, when the decision was announced that Protestant contributors were barred from voting however, they did not show up. Although some Protestant representatives did attend in later years, by 1555 the division between the Papacy and the Reformers was more or less solidified. 

Although anathematizing multiple key Protestant beliefs, by the end of Trent their final decisions were equally as much solidifying internal issues as they were about rebutting the corrections of the Reformers. Trent remains the only official church council to make a binding pronouncement on the canon of scripture. Declaring on April 8th of 1546 in the De Canonicis Scripturis that the Latin Vulgate was the official Bible of the church and affirmed the statement of Florence that scripture includes 73 books, anathematizing those who held a differing view. 

This position was nonetheless controversial even amongst the representatives at Trent. Bishop Bonuccio, attending Trent in 1546, following the Canonicis Scripturis that "The council should not try to resolve questions long disputed among reputable theologians…”

As John O’Malley in “Trent, what happened at the council” says: “That absolutely crucial qualification of the decree may have been clear to the prelates at the council, but the text they produced gave no hint of it... In this case at least, the council itself must be held responsible for the misunderstanding." 

Prior to Trent there was no official and binding Roman Catholic views on the canon of scripture.

title: I’m an indie film reference
The battle that Changed Emperor Constantine
description:
In 312 AD Constantine the Great faced off against Maxentius, the son of Maximian, the co-Augustus with Diocletian, at Milvian Bridge in Rome. Constantine marched his troops from Gaul, over the Western Alps, into North Italy.  At four cities he engages Maxentius’s army in battle and won each time, finally heading south to Rome. This led the final stand off between the two leaders of the East and Western Roman Empire.

Maxentius destroyed the bridges crossing the Tiber, making it difficult for Constantine to amass a coherent and directed assault. At the site of the Milvian Bridge north of the city, Maxentius had a temporary pontoon bridge built.  He crossed it with his army and awaited Constantine. 

According to Eusebius and Lactantius, the face off between Constantine and Maxentius marked the beginning of Constantine's conversion to Christianity. Eusebius says that Constantine had a vision, hearing the words “Ἐν Τούτῳ Νίκα,” “in this (image) conquer” and the image of ☧ , a  Chi-Rho, the first two letters of the word “Christ” in Greek.

Taken as God’s declaration of victory for the soon-to-be-Emperor. The ☧ was painted on all of Constantine’s soldiers's shields.

title: Did you know there’s a famous story in the Bible that not actually part of the Bible?
If you’ve ever opened up to John 5:4 in a modern English Bible you might have noticed it’s not there
I was recently in Egypt taking a look at some ancient copies of Gnostic literature.
Does the Gospel of Luke even claim to be history?
description:
You might not have realized it but Luke goes to lengths to demonstrate that his narrative is placed within an actual time and location. In the first two verses of Luke 3 we are not only given seven historical characters that mark out the beginning of the ministry of John the Baptist, but within these two verses alone are 22 historical references to locations and people that have been verified by archaeology and ancient literary sources outside of the Bible. 

This places Luke’s account within a historical framework. Making sure his readers know he’s not merely making up a story, but pinpointing when and where these events actually took place in history. 

And the Gospel authors do this in multiple different ways: with names, locations, as well as with accurate plant and animal life related in areas within the narratives they’re describing.

title: Can I Trust the Bible? | Official Trailer | Apologetics Canada
description:
Sign up to get your FREE COPY of the series at https://bible.apologeticscanada.com.

The Bible is the most important book of the last two millennia. From sitting at the formation of governments, cultures, and law, this collection of ancient documents has shaped the modern world in ways you may have never realized. However, while the Bible's influence has remained, central attitudes towards it have radically shifted. Once referred to as "the Good Book," many view the Bible with skepticism or downright distaste.

Are there good reasons to take the Bible seriously? Can we even have confidence that it hasn't been altered, adapted, influenced, and edited since its last book was penned nearly two thousand years ago? What are the implications if the Bible's claims are true?

My colleague Andy and I recently headed to Egypt to work on a new video project to explore questions about the most impactful book humanity has ever read.

title: Are the biblical Gospels biography?
description: On a recent podcast interview I was asked about the biblical Gospels and their place within the broader field of ancient biography and historiography. Here’s part of how I answered that question.

title: You should stop comparing the New Testament to other ancient documents
description:
There’s a popular image I regularly see being passed around the internet that compares the number of New Testament manuscripts and their closeness to the original writings of those documents over and against other writings from the ancient world. Heck! If you’ve seen presentations from me given more than 5 years ago you might have even heard or seen that information from me! 

The message is compelling: the biblical New Testament has thousands more copies and the earliest ones are hundreds of years earlier than other ancient writings. 

However, I no longer use those images and I dissuade others from doing so as well. The reason? It’s a compelling but not completely accurate portrayal of the information. 

The Bible remains the most attested document within all of antiquity, it can stand on good arguments and defences. The comparative analysis between the New Testament and other ancient writings though, is not one of the good ones.

title: Is Bill Maher right about December 25th and Christmas?
description: Bill Maher recently went on his HBO show, Real Time, to repeat an old tired argument about Christmas’ date of Dec. 25th being stollen from previous religious figures. This argument, which has no basis in anything historical and continues to exist solely by repitition (mainly on the internet) has been addressed AD NAUSEAM. Nonetheless, despite dozens of qualified individuals pointing these things out I will add to the overwhelming noise just for the sake of clarity. If people insist on repeating nonsense I will do my best to continue to correct it. Play stupid games — win stupid prizes.

title: Did Emperor Constantine change Christian worship to Sunday?
description: There's a common accusation out there that (apparently among numerous other things which he never actually did) Constantine the Great, the Emperor of Rome in the 4th century, changed the day of Christian worship from the Jewish Sabbath of Saturday to Sunday. This of course isn't true, and here I talk about it in a clip taken from an interview I did a couple of years back with @Doreen_Virtue on all things Constantine.

One that is easily (and understandably) overlooked when you read through the Gospels is the correlation of name accuracy for the exact time and place they claim to be writing.

description: Are those “lost Gospels” really lost? What do the Christians from the 2nd century — some of which who might have known followers of Jesus’ own disciples — say about what Gospels do and do not have credibility to going back to Jesus and the earliest Christian communities?

title: Getting closer to the text
description: We’re almost 2000 years removed from the most recent text of the Bible being written, so as time goes on we’re obviously getting FARTHER from the text of the Bible, right? Yes… but not so fast.

description: The biblical books aren’t history, right? After all, the stories of Jesus are just religiously oriented theological writings. How would we even begin to situate something like the gospels within an historical timeline? Well, Luke gives us a few clues, here’s just one.

title: Is the Bible we have what the original authors even wrote?
description:
Joe Rogan, David Cross, even Bart Ehrman, all accuse the biblical text of being a "translation of a translation of a translation." Is this an accurate critique? I tackled that question recently while speaking at Briercrest University.

Apologetics Canada: https://apologeticscanada.com/
Wes Huff: https://www.wesleyhuff.com/

title: Undesigned coincidences and the feeding of the 5000
description:
Undesigned coincidences are internal markers that highlight signs of authenticity within multiple written accounts, in this case for the biblical gospels. Within this argument separate authors show agreement within the details of the narrative of a kind that is hard to imagine if they were deliberately contrived for the purpose of faking authenticity. 

This agreement tends to be subtle but ultimately points to the reality of independent eyewitness testimony. The plausibility of the gospel authors getting this type of background agreement on details right independent of one another is rather implausible.  

The biblical gospels (and Acts) are chock full of these kind of internal verifications. Something that is notably missing from the later apocryphal gospel literature that starts to arise in the decades and centuries after Jesus.

title: Visiting Auschwitz
The importance of writing in Ancient Egypt
description:
While visiting the temple of Luxor in Egypt, which was active in 1400 BC, I couldn’t help but notice that the pillars in the temple were in the shape of papyrus bundles. Papyrus, the reed which grew along the River Nile, when sliced, pressed, layered, and dried, became the primary medium of writing within antiquity.

P.S. forgive my appearance it’s 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) out here.

title: The discovery of the Gospel of Thomas!
description:
In 1945 many things were happening in Europe and the Pacific Theater, not many people were paying attention to a shepherd in the backwater of Egypt. But quietly behind the scenes, a sheep herder and farmer named Muhammad Ali, together with a companion, dug up 4 foot high jar from the ground in Upper Egypt. The contents of that jar included books, texts that portrayed a radically different Jesus from the one’s in the biblical Gospels. Now known as the Nag Hammadi Library, chief of those writings was a document now referred to as The Gospel of Thomas.

The Gospel of Thomas is one of, if not the, earliest extant non-canonical Gospel accounts. However, unlike many other Gospels (both biblical and apocryphal) Thomas contains no narrative and only a list of 114 sayings between Jesus and his immediate followers. Many have argued that Thomas deserves to be in the Bible and represents an early sect of Christianity that was merely dismissed by the orthodox Christian church during its time of popularity. Others have pointed to the portrayal of Jesus within the Gospel of Thomas as evidence that Christianity was widely diverse in its beliefs and practice and that what we today call “historical Christianity” is merely the faith of the theological winners of the environment of the first few centuries AD. When it comes to the composition of this particular document the scholarly community is torn. The majority of scholars place it somewhere in the middle to late second century. A handful of scholars, including John Dominic Crossan and Elaine Pagals, place Thomas within the first century. Yet those who conclude that the Gospel of Thomas precedes the year 100 AD remain a fringe minority.Thomas is a philosophical syncretism of Gnostic ideas (of which can be placed no later than the early second century) and the Jesus tradition. The Jesus of Thomas is palatable for a gentile audience who would see no problem with the mystic Jesus Thomas portrays. If we try to attempt placing the Gospel of Thomas before the canonical four it makes little sense to then say that the Gospel authors took this Greek philosopher Jesus and proceeded to dress him in Jewish garments. Especially considering that the Christian movement became increasingly more gentile as time went on. In my estimation it would make far more sense to take the Jewish Rabbi Jesus, and dress him up as a Greek mystic philosopher than the other way around.

title: The most important archaeological cite for manususcripts
description:
Today we visited the site of the ancient Hellenistic Egyptian city of Oxyrhynchus. 

In 1895, Bernard Grenfell, fresh graduate from Queen’s College Oxford, along with his friend Aruthur Hunt, set out on an expedition from England to Egypt. Sponsored by the Egypt Exploration Fund, the goal of their project was unique for the time – a mission dedicated not to finding monumental architecture or statuary, which was a primary goal of archaeology at the time, but papyri in buried Egyptian towns.

On Dec. 20, 1896, Grenfell and Hunt arrived at Oxyrhynchus, now called El Bahnasa. After searching the remains of the town and its cemeteries with little success, Grenfell and Hunt turned their attention to the many high mounds of rubbish that dotted the landscape. It was here, in the midst of several centuries’ worth of accumulated trash, that success came in a swift and spectacular fashion. During the winter of 1896, while sifting through a number of papyrus, Grenfell Hunt noticed a piece of papyri written on both sides. After clearing it off he read from the neat, clean, capital Greek letters, identifying it as containing the first chapters of the Gospel of Matthew.

In fact, Oxyhrynchus to this day still has papyri from Christian and Classical origins being pulled from its sands, of the published papyri almost 5 ½ thousand have been published, but tens of thousands remain in waiting for examination, translation, and transcription.

title: Where they found the Rosetta Stone!
description:
Today I visited the town of Rashid, Egypt. Between 1798-1801 Napoleon Bonaparte campaigned in Egypt with the purpose of controlling the entire Mediterranean and threatening the British’s hold on India. 

On July 15 1799, while reinforcing and renovating the citadel at Rashid, a French officer stumbled upon the large engraved stone built into the foundation. Seeing its possible significance it was moved and stored. Upon Napoleon’s defeat and under the Treaty of Alexandria the stone became British property. 

It wouldn’t be until 1822 when the French scholar Jean-Francois Champollion was able to figure out how to back translate the Greek and Demotic when the secret of how to read hieroglyphics was cracked.

title: The Septuagint is the most important Bible you've never heard of
description:
The importance of the Greek translation of the Old Testament for the textual history of Scripture in both Hebrew and Greek and in both the Old and New Testament is invaluable! It encompassed a major part of the textual environment of second temple Judaism and early Christianity both in terms of number of copies and in the influence of those copies on other writers and scribes. Yet, thinking of the Septuagint as a single document or unit may actually be detrimental to how it operated and functioned within the ancient world.

title: Why do the Gospels disagree on the time of Jesus' death?
description:
Taken from a Facebook Live Q&A event. Here is my answer to the question I was asked that “Mark and John appear to be giving different times of crucifixion for Jesus, how is this not a contradiction?”

*point of correction: 
- at 1:21 I mispeak and include John in the list of Synoptic Gospels. The Synoptics are only Matthew, Mark, and Luke. 
- at 2:09 I misspeak and say 6 AM when I should have said 6 PM (I.e. sunset - think of the “evening and morning” statements in Genesis Ch. 1).

title: The Trinity? - Walking with Wes
description:
I get a lot of questions about the doctrine of the Trinity. It doesn’t seem to matter if I’m talking to Mormons, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Muslims, or atheists, the doctrine of the Trinity they say, just doesn’t make any sense. How can you have one God but talk about three? Does one plus one plus one equal…. one?

So what’s going on here? Well first let me start off by saying that the Trinity, as it is understood biblically, teaches three fundamental truths we see in Scripture:

First, there is only one true God. From the beginning to end of the Bible we see this confessed time and time again. God via the prophet Isaiah declared that “Before me there was no God formed, and there will be none after me.” 

Secondly, that within that one true God there are three divine persons who are distinguished from one another: The Father, the Son, and the Spirit. The Father is not the Son, the Son is not the Sprit, and the Spirit is not the Father.

When Jesus prays in places like the Gospel of John chapter seventeen, he’s not praying to himself. Instead he says “glorify me with the glory I had with you in your presence before the world was. 

That’s clearly two persons speaking,  Jesus is describing a time in eternity past when He and the Father existed within company to one another. And these three are identified by the same name. And the name of God that we see in the Old Testament is Yahweh. 

New Testament passages about Yahweh are applied to both the Father and the Son and the Spirit is referred to as the Spirit of Yahweh. We even see Jesus in Matthew’s Gospel chapter twenty eight, verse nineteen, tell his followers to baptize in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. That word we translate as name in English is the Greek word “onama” and its an accusative neuter singular noun. One name, and yet it goes on to say that within that name are Father, son, and spirit. 

One God, three divine persons revealed. 

The third truth we see taught is that these person’s hold equality. And that equality doesn’t mean sameness - the Father, Son, and Spirit clearly do different things from one another, and yet are equally given the honours, the attributes, the names, and the deeds, of Yahweh God. 

So how does this really work, how can we have three in one? Well there are a couple of distinctions made, the first to remember is the distinction between “being” or “essence” and “person.”

God is one “being” but three “persons.” Being is an English word we use to describe what something is. Person is the word we use to describe who someone is. So it would make no sense if Christians believed that God was one in being and three in being - that would be a logical contradiction. Or if we said that God was one person in three persons. Once again, illogical. 

For example. I am one being - a human being, and one person - Wesley. 

But being and person are distinctive categories. And categories that accurately describe what we see when we continually read in Scripture that there is only one God, but that God the Father, Jesus, and the Holy Spirit are all called God yet still  distinguished from one another. Or as the Athanasius Creed says: this is the universal faith: that we worship one God in trinity and the trinity in unity, neither blending their persons nor dividing their essence. 

One God encompassed by three coequal, coeternal persons: The Father, the Son, and the Spirit.

title: Isn't Jesus just a copy of other ancient religious figures?
description:
Have you ever heard that Jesus is just a copycat of other ancient religious figures like Mythris, Horus, Zeus, or Adonis? This is a popular opinion on the internet with self-titled "mythicists." The problem is, the parallels aren't there to begin with! And even if they were, would it make that big of a deal? I would argue not...

title: Short example of why you can trust the Gospels as history
description:
Recently I was sent an email by a college student asking why I would trust the biblical Gospels as accurate history. Here's a part of the response I gave where I probe into John's biography of Jesus' life. There are may passages of the Bible that seem insignificant and are easy to miss, but when given their historical setting they reveal the historical goldmine the Gospels are.

description: Other non-biblical Gospels have names like "Peter" attached to them. Did Peter write the Gospel of Peter and how do we know he did or didn't? This is the answer given by Wesley Huff during a Q&A session at Queen's University after a talk on the historical case for Jesus' resurrection.

title: Resurrection Talk Conclusion - Queen's University
description:
This is the conclusion of a presentation on the historical evidence for the physical resurrection of Jesus from the dead that was given by Wesley Huff at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, Canada. 

Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. He has a BA from York University, a Masters in theology from Tyndale University, and is currently a PhD student at the University of Toronto. Wes is an an avid blogger and a contributor to the Online Apologetics Academy.  After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of 11 that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery that the doctors said they had no medical explanation for. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teens  solidified his interest in the subjects of faith, and engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He has been participating in public dialogues on issues of faith, belief, and religion for the last seven years. He enjoys canoeing, archery, and cats (although not all three at the same time). Wes lives with his wife, Melissa in Toronto, Ontario.

title: Wesley Huff, SEEN testimony Video
description:
This video was taken as part of the  annual Power to Change Students 2017 P2C Plus Conference, which took place in Toronto, Ontario Canada. The theme of the conference was "Seen by God." 

In this video Wesley, a writer, researcher, and speaker with Power to Change's Ultimate Questions speaking team shares his  personal testimony about being a paraplegic and experiencing a miraculous healing. Just before Wesley's 12th birthday he was diagnosed with acute transverse myelitis, a rare condition that left him paralyzed from the waist down. Although he was told that he would most likely never walk and probably never run again, one month from the day that he woke up and was paralyzed from the waist down he woke up on a Saturday morning walked over to his wheelchair and sat down.

Wesley went on to have a successful athletics career in high school and with the York University track & field team. Having the privilege to be part of 2 U Sports (formerly Canadian Interuniversity Sports) national gold medal 4x200m relay teams. Along with being part of the overall mens track & field champions in 2014. He is currently a PhD student at the University of Toronto's Wycliffe college and regularly speaks at conferences, churches, and on University campuses on a variety of topics relating to faith, worldview issues, and apologetics.

title: Is Tolerance Intolerant? McGill University
description:
"Is Tolerance Tolerant?" is a presentation done at Power to Change McGill's regular "Ultimate Question" series. 

Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. He has a BA in Sociology from York University, a Masters from Tyndale University, and is a PhD student in New Testament at the University of Toronto. While being an avid blogger, he is a contributor to the Gospel Coalition Canada, the Online Apologetics Academy, and has written numerous entries for the Melton’s Encyclopedia of American Religions (9th Ed.). Wesley has a passion for the study of the historical reliability of the Bible, focusing a great deal of both his personal and formal study on the academic field of textual criticism. After growing up in majority Muslim countries, his areas of interest also include inter-faith dialogue between Islam and Christianity, primarily in the textual histories of the Bible and Qur’an.

After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of 11 that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery that the doctors themselves said they had no medical explanation for. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teens, is what solidified his interest in the subjects of faith, and engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He has been participating in public dialogues on issues of faith, belief, and religion for the last six years. An avid athlete, during his undergrad he competed nationally as a varsity athlete on the York University track and field team. He enjoys canoeing, archery, and cats (although not all three at the same time). Wes lives in Toronto with his wife Melissa.

title: Transmission of the New Testament - RELEVANT Series Q&A
description:
Wesley Huff, of the Power to Change Apologetics Team, answers a question regarding the reliability of the text of the biblical New Testament. This video is taken from the Q&A for the talk "The Bible: Fact or Fiction" during the RELEVANT Series at the University of Toronto. Following a talk by RZIM Canada's Logan Gates, panelists Joshua Echebiri and Wesley Huff joined Logan to answered questions regarding the Bible and the Christian faith (moderated by RZIM's Michelle Tepper). 

The RELEVANT Series took place at the University of Toronto's Wycliffe College during the week of January 16th, 2017. The Series was put together by Power to Change in conjunction with Ravi Zacharias International Ministries (Canada) and the Network of Christian Scholars. For more information regarding the RELEVANT Series see http://relevantseries.com; for more information regarding Power to Change Apologetics and Wesley Huff see http://wesleyhuff.blogspot.ca/p/my-ministry.html

title: Responding to Bart Ehrman's 'Misquoting Jesus'  on the Apologetics Academy Webinar
description:
This is taken from the Apologetics Academy Webinar (http://apologetics-academy.org/) hosted by Jonathan McLatchie. 

In my talk I describe who Bart Ehrman is, I give a synopsis of the book, and then I go through my positives and negatives of Ehrman's work.

Wesley is currently a full time Christian apologist with the Power to Change Apologetics team. He has a passion for the study of the reliability of the Scriptures and his graduate studies have focused on the field of textual criticism. After growing up in majority Muslim countries, his areas of interest also include inter-faith dialogue between Islam and Christianity, primarily in the textual histories of the Bible and Qur'an. He has been participating in public dialogues about Christianity for the last six years. An avid athlete, during his undergrad studies he was a member of York U's varsity track & field team. Wes lives in Toronto, Canada with his wife. 

For more info please contact: wesley.huff@p2c.com
For articles and blog posts by Wesley: http://wesleyhuff.blogspot.ca
